alternatives.transcript: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. You know, 1 of the classic things we serve in France in many bistros is called the croque monsieur. And this is very simply done with gruyere and ham. So here I use the slice of Swiss cheese. If you can have a Montalor or whatever, it's even better. And on top of this, you put your ham. I cut it this way so that I have a straight edge here. Something on the other side. Those are Very thin slice of ham, so I think I'll put another 1. Then another piece of cheese on top. Finally, the bread. So you do 2 sandwich like this. And this are served in a bistro. Sometimes there is what they call the croque madame, which now I know in many recipes are the fried eggs on top. I remember doing it in Paris. It never had eggs on top. It was done exactly the same than that, except it was chicken rather than ham. But, things change. This. Okay, and then we're gonna butter the top on each side. So we use about Close to a teaspoon of butter on each side. And that's going to go into the oven. Can be 350, 400 degree, doesn't really matter. It will take about, it's gonna take about 10, 12 minutes. We'll see. Okay. Now My croque monsieur are cooked. This is still hot. It's out of the oven like 5 minutes. Let it cool off a little bit. The whole croque monsieur, usually we trim it like this. And even when I was a kid, we loved those trimming. And cut it, it's very in half this way. As you can see the cheese is very soft. And that's not the way you would serve the croque monsieur there once or some other time. And often I do this for, for hors d'oeuvre when I have to pass hors d'oeuvre and I do the, don't really have to cream it. And then I cut those in at least, sometimes 6 piece or 8 piece. Little croque monsieur like this, that you pass around for aperitif. It's a nice hors d'oeuvre. Still hot inside. Okay. It's a nice hors d'oeuvre to pass around like this. Easy to do. You can do that way ahead. Put the butter on top, ready to go into the oven, and whenever you need it, you shut it. And this is the Cote Monsieur. Happy cooking. ♪♪

paragraphs.transcript:
Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. You know, 1 of the classic things we serve in France in many bistros is called the croque monsieur. And this is very simply done with gruyere and ham. So here I use the slice of Swiss cheese. If you can have a Montalor or whatever, it's even better.

And on top of this, you put your ham. I cut it this way so that I have a straight edge here. Something on the other side. Those are Very thin slice of ham, so I think I'll put another 1. Then another piece of cheese on top.

Finally, the bread. So you do 2 sandwich like this. And this are served in a bistro. Sometimes there is what they call the croque madame, which now I know in many recipes are the fried eggs on top. I remember doing it in Paris.

It never had eggs on top. It was done exactly the same than that, except it was chicken rather than ham. But, things change. This. Okay, and then we're gonna butter the top on each side.

So we use about Close to a teaspoon of butter on each side. And that's going to go into the oven. Can be 350, 400 degree, doesn't really matter. It will take about, it's gonna take about 10, 12 minutes. We'll see.

Okay. Now My croque monsieur are cooked. This is still hot. It's out of the oven like 5 minutes. Let it cool off a little bit.

The whole croque monsieur, usually we trim it like this. And even when I was a kid, we loved those trimming. And cut it, it's very in half this way. As you can see the cheese is very soft. And that's not the way you would serve the croque monsieur there once or some other time.

And often I do this for, for hors d'oeuvre when I have to pass hors d'oeuvre and I do the, don't really have to cream it. And then I cut those in at least, sometimes 6 piece or 8 piece. Little croque monsieur like this, that you pass around for aperitif. It's a nice hors d'oeuvre. Still hot inside.

Okay. It's a nice hors d'oeuvre to pass around like this. Easy to do. You can do that way ahead. Put the butter on top, ready to go into the oven, and whenever you need it, you shut it.

And this is the Cote Monsieur. Happy cooking. ♪♪

sentences.text: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home.
You know, 1 of the classic things we serve in France in many bistros is called the croque monsieur.
And this is very simply done with gruyere and ham.
So here I use the slice of Swiss cheese.
If you can have a Montalor or whatever, it's even better.
And on top of this, you put your ham.
I cut it this way so that I have a straight edge here.
Something on the other side.
Those are Very thin slice of ham, so I think I'll put another 1.
Then another piece of cheese on top.
Finally, the bread.
So you do 2 sandwich like this.
And this are served in a bistro.
Sometimes there is what they call the croque madame, which now I know in many recipes are the fried eggs on top.
I remember doing it in Paris.
It never had eggs on top.
It was done exactly the same than that, except it was chicken rather than ham.
But, things change.
This.
Okay, and then we're gonna butter the top on each side.
So we use about Close to a teaspoon of butter on each side.
And that's going to go into the oven.
Can be 350, 400 degree, doesn't really matter.
It will take about, it's gonna take about 10, 12 minutes.
We'll see.
Okay.
Now My croque monsieur are cooked.
This is still hot.
It's out of the oven like 5 minutes.
Let it cool off a little bit.
The whole croque monsieur, usually we trim it like this.
And even when I was a kid, we loved those trimming.
And cut it, it's very in half this way.
As you can see the cheese is very soft.
And that's not the way you would serve the croque monsieur there once or some other time.
And often I do this for, for hors d'oeuvre when I have to pass hors d'oeuvre and I do the, don't really have to cream it.
And then I cut those in at least, sometimes 6 piece or 8 piece.
Little croque monsieur like this, that you pass around for aperitif.
It's a nice hors d'oeuvre.
Still hot inside.
Okay.
It's a nice hors d'oeuvre to pass around like this.
Easy to do.
You can do that way ahead.
Put the butter on top, ready to go into the oven, and whenever you need it, you shut it.
And this is the Cote Monsieur.
Happy cooking.
